items.title: Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve.
items.body:
## Current Behavior
conda install is giving error "Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve." in Anaconda Powershell Promt (Miniconda3)


### Steps to Reproduce
I am trying to install bowtie and salmon using these commands:
```
conda install bowtie
```
```
conda install -c bioconda salmon
```
I have tried both as base and opencv but the the same error comes up.

## Expected Behavior
It should install Bowtie and Salmon packages


## Environment Information
```
(base) PS C:\> conda install -c bioconda salmon
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve.

PackagesNotFoundError: The following packages are not available from current channels:

  - salmon

Current channels:

  - https://conda.anaconda.org/bioconda/win-64
  - https://conda.anaconda.org/bioconda/noarch
```

items.title: Illegal Instruction 24731 while Installing Miniconda
items.body:
## Current Behavior
<!-- What actually happens?
     If you want to include console output, please use "Steps to Reproduce" below. -->

Miniconda Installation on yocto-Linux fails during intermediate python 3.7 installation.

Similar issues: #9164 

### Steps to Reproduce
<!-- If the current behavior is a bug, please provide specific, minimal steps to independently reproduce.
     Include the exact conda commands that reproduce the issue and their output between the ticks below. -->

After downloading the appropriate installer (https://repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/Miniconda3-latest-Linux-x86.sh) I encounter the following error during execution of the installer:

```
Miniconda3 will now be installed into this location:
/home/root/miniconda3

  - Press ENTER to confirm the location
  - Press CTRL-C to abort the installation
  - Or specify a different location below

[/home/root/miniconda3] >>> 
PREFIX=/home/root/miniconda3
installing: python-3.7.1-h0371630_7 ...
./conda.sh: line 358: 24731 Illegal instruction     "$PREFIX/pkgs/python-3.7.1-h0371630_7/bin/python" -E -s "$PREFIX"/pkgs/.install.py $INST_OPT --root-prefix="$PREFIX" --link-dist="$1"
```


## Expected Behavior
<!-- What do you think should happen? -->
Installation _should_ be able to proceed as normal.

## Environment Information

Distribution: [Miniconda 3, Linux Installer, 32-bit](https://repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/Miniconda3-latest-Linux-x86.sh)
OS: Linux 3.8.7-yocto-standard i586
Device: Intel Galileo

items.title: Cannot specify version number for one package among many even though, left unspecified, it installs the version number I am trying to specify
items.body:
**I'm submitting a...** - [x] bug report - [ ] feature request ## Current Behavior Amidst a long list of fully specified conda python packages in a YAML file - `sqlite` works and conda installs version 3.23.3 - `sqlite==3.23.3` fails with the error _ResolvePackageNotFound: sqlite==3.23.3_ - `sqlite==3.23.*` fails with huge error message starting _Found conflicts_ ### Steps to Reproduce I have the following YAML file to create a conda environment. ``` name: test1 channels: - defaults - pytorch - conda-forge dependencies: - coverage==5.0 - cudatoolkit==10.2.89 - dataclasses==0.7 - future==0.18.2 - joblib==0.16.0 - jupyter==1.0.0 - keyring==21.2.1 - matplotlib==3.2.2 - mypy==0.782 - numpy==1.19.1 - pandas==0.25.3 - param==1.9.2 - pip==20.2.2 - pylint==2.5.3 - python==3.8.5 - python-dateutil==2.8.1 - pytorch==1.6.0 - pyyaml==5.3.1 - scikit-learn==0.23.1 - scipy==1.5.0 - seaborn==0.10.1 - sqlite - tensorboard==2.2.1 - torchvision==0.7.0 - visdom==0.1.8.9 ``` It works fine. When I activate the environment and check the package versions I find that the only package I did not specify a version number for (`sqlite`) it has been found as ``` > Name Version Build Channel > sqlite 3.32.3 h2a8f88b_0 ``` But if I try to peg sqlite to that version number it fails. For example this config file ``` name: test2 channels: - defaults - pytorch - conda-forge dependencies: - coverage==5.0 - cudatoolkit==10.2.89 - dataclasses==0.7 - future==0.18.2 - joblib==0.16.0 - jupyter==1.0.0 - keyring==21.2.1 - matplotlib==3.2.2 - mypy==0.782 - numpy==1.19.1 - pandas==0.25.3 - param==1.9.2 - pip==20.2.2 - pylint==2.5.3 - python==3.8.5 - python-dateutil==2.8.1 - pytorch==1.6.0 - pyyaml==5.3.1 - scikit-learn==0.23.1 - scipy==1.5.0 - seaborn==0.10.1 - sqlite==3.23.3 - tensorboard==2.2.1 - torchvision==0.7.0 - visdom==0.1.8.9 ``` gives the error ``` > ResolvePackageNotFound: > - sqlite==3.23.3 ``` while this config file ``` name: test3 channels: - defaults - pytorch - conda-forge dependencies: - coverage==5.0 - cudatoolkit==10.2.89 - dataclasses==0.7 - future==0.18.2 - joblib==0.16.0 - jupyter==1.0.0 - keyring==21.2.1 - matplotlib==3.2.2 - mypy==0.782 - numpy==1.19.1 - pandas==0.25.3 - param==1.9.2 - pip==20.2.2 - pylint==2.5.3 - python==3.8.5 - python-dateutil==2.8.1 - pytorch==1.6.0 - pyyaml==5.3.1 - scikit-learn==0.23.1 - scipy==1.5.0 - seaborn==0.10.1 - sqlite==3.23.* - tensorboard==2.2.1 - torchvision==0.7.0 - visdom==0.1.8.9 ``` gives a 371 line error message starting ``` > Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages. ``` ## Expected Behavior I should be able to specify the version of sqlite package using either `sqlite==3.23.3` or `sqlite==3.23.*` ## Environment Information
`conda info`

``` active environment : test1 active env location : C:\Users\timregan\Miniconda3\envs\test1 shell level : 3 user config file : C:\Users\timregan\.condarc populated config files : conda version : 4.8.4 conda-build version : not installed python version : 3.8.3.final.0 virtual packages : base environment : C:\Users\timregan\Miniconda3 (writable) channel URLs : https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/msys2/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/msys2/noarch package cache : C:\Users\timregan\Miniconda3\pkgs C:\Users\timregan\.conda\pkgs C:\Users\timregan\AppData\Local\conda\conda\pkgs envs directories : C:\Users\timregan\Miniconda3\envs C:\Users\timregan\.conda\envs C:\Users\timregan\AppData\Local\conda\conda\envs platform : win-64 user-agent : conda/4.8.4 requests/2.24.0 CPython/3.8.3 Windows/10 Windows/10.0.19041 administrator : False netrc file : None offline mode : False ```

items.title: tensorflow installattion error on conda
items.body:
I tried to install TensorFlow in anaconda and this is what happens. What should I do?


<!Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve.
Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source.
Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done
Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve.
Solving environment: /
Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages.
This can take several minutes.  Press CTRL-C to abort.
failed

UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found
to be incompatible with the existing python installation in your environment:

Specifications:

  - tensorflow -> python[version='3.5.*|3.6.*|3.7.*']

Your python: python=3.8

If python is on the left-most side of the chain, that's the version you've asked for.
When python appears to the right, that indicates that the thing on the left is somehow
not available for the python version you are constrained to. Note that conda will not
change your python version to a different minor version unless you explicitly specify
that.

The following specifications were found to be incompatible with your CUDA driver:

  - feature:/win-64::__cuda==10.1=0

Your installed CUDA driver is: 10.1

items.title: "conda run" command missing output
items.body:
## Introduction It seems that `conda run` command only show the outputs when the execution is over, but not interactively show the outputs. I wrote a little demo do demonstrate this problem. ## Step to Reproduce `conda.exe run -n any-env python IOtest.py` ``` # IOtest.py for i in range(5): a = input("input:") print(a) ``` ### Current Behavior ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53651354/90259626-ed7e2680-de7c-11ea-80bc-347b67abe394.png) (the top 5 lines are my input, and the rest are the output) ``` ``` ## Expected Behavior ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53651354/90260181-bc522600-de7d-11ea-865a-8bf8a79af08e.png) ## Environment Information

items.title: Replication of issue from conda-forge: Unable to install WeasyPrint under Python 3.8
items.body:
## Current Behavior Cannot install WeasyPrint from conda-forge due to unsatisfiable requirements that are NOT specified in the package itself with no explanation where they are from. I would like to install the weasyprint package but it fails due to unsatisfiable requirements (see below for full output.). I filed this in the correct conda-forge repo but they cannot explain it either as there are no requirements defined in the repo so we (conda-forge maintainers and myself) have no idea where they come from? Is this caused by conda or does anyone have an idea where those requirements come from? See also https://github.com/conda-forge/weasyprint-feedstock/issues/8 in the conda-forge repo. ### Steps to Reproduce ``` conda install -c conda-forge weasyprint ``` ## Expected Behavior Successful installation of the package. ## Actual Behavior ``` (environment) username@My-MBP ~ % conda install -c conda-forge weasyprint Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve. Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source. Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve. Solving environment: / Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages. This can take several minutes. Press CTRL-C to abort. failed UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be incompatible with the existing python installation in your environment: Specifications: - weasyprint -> python[version='2.7.*|3.5.*|3.6.*|3.6.9|3.6.9|3.6.9|>=2.7,<2.8.0a0|>=3.5|>=3.6,<3.7.0a0|>=3.8,<3.9.0a0|>=3.5,<3.6.0a0|3.4.*|>3.5',build='0_73_pypy|1_73_pypy|2_73_pypy'] - weasyprint -> python[version='>=3.7,<3.8.0a0'] Your python: python=3.8 If python is on the left-most side of the chain, that's the version you've asked for. When python appears to the right, that indicates that the thing on the left is somehow not available for the python version you are constrained to. items.title: Cannot import spacy + no 'importlib_metadata' package after conda update conda
items.body:
Hi, recently I have started to use spacy with my team to do some NLP analysis. I had installed the package through the conda forge channel, as indicated in the spacy website. Now, I had to update scikit-learn from 0.22 to 0.23 to run some other people analysis and therefore I proceed with the following: conda update conda (in the root environment) and scikit-learn was updated to the latest version 0.23.1. Afterwordws I had tried to run "jupyter notebook" from the root and it was not working due to some jsonschema dependency. I had downgraded jsonschema == 3.0.2 and now the jupyter notebook can be launched but spaCy cannot be imported. I have the following error: Python 3.7.3 (default, Mar 27 2019, 16:54:48) [Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)] :: Anaconda, Inc. on darwin Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information. >>> import spacy Traceback (most recent call last): File "/Users/tommaso/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/catalogue.py", line 8, in import importlib.metadata as importlib_metadata ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'importlib.metadata' During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred: Traceback (most recent call last): File "", line 1, in File "/Users/tommaso/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/spacy/__init__.py", line 10, in from thinc.neural.util import prefer_gpu, require_gpu File "/Users/tommaso/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/thinc/__init__.py", line 8, in from ._registry import registry File "/Users/tommaso/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/thinc/_registry.py", line 1, in import catalogue File "/Users/tommaso/anaconda3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/catalogue.py", line 10, in import importlib_metadata ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'importlib_metadata' I would expect spacy to be loaded normally, as I have just updated the conda environment. at the same time once I do a conda list I can see both the following packages installed: importlib-metadata 1.7.0 py37hc8dfbb8_0 conda-forge importlib_metadata 1.7.0 0 conda-forge It's two days I am trying to solve this issue without having to reinstall anaconda/python. Any help from the community? ## Environment Information
`conda info`

items.title: Hello, conda install is too slow, it takes more than 30 mins to install while other packages take less time. I am working on IBM Watson studio, thought it is worth mentioning.
items.body:
## Steps to Reproduce * On unix (bash shells): CONDA_INSTRUMENTATION_ENABLED=1 -vv | tee conda_debug_output.txt * On Windows: set CONDA_INSTRUMENTATION_ENABLED=1 powershell " -vv | tee conda_debug_output.txt" --> ``` ! conda install -c conda-forge descartes=1.1.0 --yes ! conda install -c conda-forge geopandas=0.8.0 --yes import geopandas as gpd import descartes ``` ``` < paste contents of ~/.conda/instrumentation-record.csv here, or attach it as a file to this report > ``` ## Environment Information

items.title: Pyembed could not build a python embedded interpreter
items.body:
## Current Behavior Attempting to use pyembed of python-config from a conda installation to create an embedded python interpreter for use with waf. When doing this pyembed can be found but it cannot build the embedded interpreter. Changing python versions does not help, but I have seen suggestions that the problem goes away when using a local python installation instead. ### Steps to Reproduce Create a python 3 environment then ask python-config for pyembed using either ```'--cflags --libs --ldflags --embed' flags ``` if it is python 3.8 or``` '--cflags --libs --ldflags' flags ```if it is <= 3.7 This will generate the error. I am using waf to build a different application which uses the python interpreter so I do not fully know how the commands are requested, however you can follow along if you like for building ns3 using the tar ball. https://www.nsnam.org/docs/release/3.31/tutorial/singlehtml/index.html ## Expected Behavior It should successfully build the embedded interpreter. ## Environment Information
`conda info`

``` conda version : 4.8.4 conda-build version : 3.18.11 python version : 3.7.7.final.0 virtual packages : __glibc=2.31 base environment : /home/my_usr/anaconda3 (writable) channel URLs : https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/linux-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/linux-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/noarch package cache : /home/my_usr/anaconda3/pkgs /home/my_usr/.conda/pkgs envs directories : /home/my_usr/anaconda3/envs /home/my_usr/.conda/envs platform : linux-64 user-agent : conda/4.8.4 requests/2.24.0 CPython/3.7.7 Linux/5.8.0-050800-generic ubuntu/20.04.1 glibc/2.31 UID:GID : 1000:1000 netrc file : None offline mode : False ```

`conda config --show-sources`

this returns a blank line

items.title: `conda install nb_conda` fails on default Anaconda3-2020.07-Linux-x86_64 install.
items.body:
## Current Behavior `conda install nb_conda` fails as per provided output on a fresh Anaconda3-2020.07-Linux-x86_64 install. ### Steps to Reproduce ``` (base) anaconda@anaconda:~$ conda install nb_conda Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve. Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source. Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed with initial frozen solve. Retrying with flexible solve. Solving environment: | Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages. This can take several minutes. Press CTRL-C to abort. failed UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be incompatible with the existing python installation in your environment: Specifications: - nb_conda -> python[version='>=2.7,<2.8.0a0|>=3.6,<3.7.0a0|>=3.7,<3.8.0a0|>=3.5,<3.6.0a0'] Your python: python=3.8 If python is on the left-most side of the chain, that's the version you've asked for. When python appears to the right, that indicates that the thing on the left is somehow not available for the python version you are constrained to. Note that conda will not change your python version to a different minor version unless you explicitly specify that. ``` ## Expected Behavior To be able to install the jupyter extensions per documentation [https://docs.anaconda.com/anaconda/user-guide/tasks/use-jupyter-notebook-extensions/](url) with `conda install conda_nb`. ## Environment Information
`conda info`

``` (base) anaconda@anaconda:~$ conda info active environment : base active env location : /home/anaconda/anaconda3 shell level : 1 user config file : /home/anaconda/.condarc populated config files : conda version : 4.8.3 conda-build version : 3.18.11 python version : 3.8.3.final.0 virtual packages : __glibc=2.28 base environment : /home/anaconda/anaconda3 (writable) channel URLs : https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/linux-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/linux-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/noarch package cache : /home/anaconda/anaconda3/pkgs /home/anaconda/.conda/pkgs envs directories : /home/anaconda/anaconda3/envs /home/anaconda/.conda/envs platform : linux-64 user-agent : conda/4.8.3 requests/2.24.0 CPython/3.8.3 Linux/4.19.0-10-amd64 debian/10 glibc/2.28 UID:GID : 1001:1001 netrc file : None offline mode : False ```

items.body:
Hello i tried for two days to find the solution on the internet and I wasn't successful to solve this problem, I have a fresh windows 7 64 bits , the windows I used before this one things worked just fine, since I'm new with anaconda I'm stuck and lost.

items.title: How to set package priorities?
items.body:
I try to update my environment with:
```
~> conda update --all
Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done
Solving environment: done

## Package Plan ##

  environment location: 


The following packages will be downloaded:

    package                    |            build
    ---------------------------|-----------------
    libblas-3.8.0              |           12_mkl          10 KB  conda-forge
    libcblas-3.8.0             |           12_mkl          10 KB  conda-forge
    liblapack-3.8.0            |           12_mkl          10 KB  conda-forge
    liblapacke-3.8.0           |           12_mkl          10 KB  conda-forge
    pandas-profiling-2.8.0     |             py_0         172 KB  conda-forge
    phonopy-2.7.1              |   py37h161383b_0         937 KB  conda-forge
    pyiron-0.2.17              |     pyh9f0ad1d_0         294 KB  conda-forge
    visions-0.4.6              |     pyh9f0ad1d_0          41 KB  conda-forge
    ------------------------------------------------------------
                                           Total:         1.4 MB

The following packages will be UPDATED:

  phonopy                              2.6.0-py37h03ebfcd_1 --> 2.7.1-py37h161383b_0
  visions                                0.4.4-pyh9f0ad1d_0 --> 0.4.6-pyh9f0ad1d_0

The following packages will be DOWNGRADED:

  libblas                                      3.8.0-14_mkl --> 3.8.0-12_mkl
  libcblas                                     3.8.0-14_mkl --> 3.8.0-12_mkl
  liblapack                                    3.8.0-14_mkl --> 3.8.0-12_mkl
  liblapacke                                   3.8.0-14_mkl --> 3.8.0-12_mkl
  pandas-profiling                       2.8.0-pyh9f0ad1d_1 --> 2.8.0-py_0
  pyiron                                0.2.17-pyh9f0ad1d_1 --> 0.2.17-pyh9f0ad1d_0
```
I do not want these updates and it should report no updates necessary. The packages `pandas-profiling` and `pyiron` in their latest version, fix the dependencies to `visions` and `phonopy`: 

- https://github.com/conda-forge/pandas-profiling-feedstock/pull/29
- https://github.com/conda-forge/pyiron-feedstock/pull/31

Still conda prefers to downgrade `pandas-profiling` and `pyiron` to update `visions` and `phonopy` which is not what I want. Should not the the dependent package have the highest priority?

items.title: Create Environment from URL of environmnent.yml file
items.body:
Hi,

A recurring challenge when working with people new to git, conda, and the terminal in general, is to share a conda environment.yml file with them.  I'd love to help them set up an environment by sending them a code snippet like this:

`conda create -f https://github.com/orgname/projectname/blob/master/environment.yml`

Is this a feature that conda can support?  My apologies if this is already available--I've searched for quite a while and haven't been able to locate this feature.  

Best wishes,

Nick

items.title: error when trying to duplication env using conda list --explicit
items.body:
## Current Behavior I tried to duplicate identical environment using [this](https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda/en/latest/user-guide/tasks/manage-environments.html#building-identical-conda-environments) official documentation and got the following error: ``` Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed ResolvePackageNotFound: - @explicit ``` I suggest create the --list without @explicit in the output or to update the documentation I pointed to.[simply add grep command on the --list output ### Steps to Reproduce ``` echo "name: koko\ndependencies:\n - python=3.7\n - lz4\n"> env.yml conda env create --file env.yml conda activate koko conda list --explicit > environment.txt conda env create --name koko_dup -f environment.txt ``` ## Expected Behavior The environment will be created without any errors. ## Environment Information

items.title: Can't publish Anaconda Navigator through the Remoteapp on a Windows Server
Trouble creating new python environment with different python version
items.body:
## Current Behavior I have an offline machine which currently doesn't have python 3.7. I cannot create a new environment with python 3.7. ### Steps to Reproduce To install the new python version, I installed the python-3.7.6-h60c2a47_5_cpython.tar from conda-forge and placed it in the /pkgs directory. I used the ```conda create --offline -n py37 python=3.7``` command. but I get the following error: ``` Fetching package metadata ............. PackageNotFoundError: Packages missing in current channels: - python 3.7* We have searched for the packages in the following channels: - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/main/win-64 - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/main/noarch - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/free/win-64 - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/free/noarch - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/r/win-64 - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/r/noarch - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/pro/win-64 - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/pro/noarch - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/msys2/win-64 - https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/msys2/noarch ``` It seems to me that the --offline option does not work. What is the fastest way to set up the new environment? ## Expected Behavior I just want to setup a new environment with a python version that is not installed on an offline machine. items.title: BUG: Conflicts with pyface >= 7 and Python >= 3.7
items.body:
## Current Behavior 1. Conda cannot create an environment without conflicts (the CUDA stuff is unrelated I think):
Traceback ``` Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done Solving environment: / Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages. This can take several minutes. Press CTRL-C to abort. failed Solving environment: / Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages. This can take several minutes. Press CTRL-C to abort. failed UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be incompatible with each other: Output in format: Requested package -> Available versions Package python conflicts for: traitsui[version='>=6'] -> pyface[version='>=6'] -> python[version='>=3.8,<3.9.0a0'] pyface[version='>=7'] -> python[version='>=3.6,<3.7.0a0|>=3.7,<3.8.0a0|>=3.8,<3.9.0a0'] pyface[version='>=7'] -> pygments -> python[version='>=2.7,<2.8.0a0|>=3.5|>=3.5,<3.6.0a0'] python[version='>=3.8'] traitsui[version='>=6'] -> python[version='>=2.7,<2.8.0a0|>=3.5,<3.6.0a0|>=3.6,<3.7.0a0|>=3.7,<3.8.0a0'] Package _libgcc_mutex conflicts for: traits[version='>=6'] -> libgcc-ng[version='>=7.3.0'] -> _libgcc_mutex=[build=main] python[version='>=3.8'] -> libgcc-ng[version='>=7.3.0'] -> _libgcc_mutex=[build=main] Package pyface conflicts for: traitsui[version='>=6'] -> pyface[version='>=6'] pyface[version='>=7'] Package traits conflicts for: traits[version='>=6'] traitsui[version='>=6'] -> traits pyface[version='>=7'] -> traits Package ca-certificates conflicts for: traitsui[version='>=6'] -> python -> ca-certificates python[version='>=3.8'] -> openssl[version='>=1.1.1g,<1.1.2a'] -> ca-certificates Package setuptools conflicts for: pyface[version='>=7'] -> pygments -> setuptools python[version='>=3.8'] -> pip -> setuptoolsThe following specifications were found to be incompatible with your CUDA driver: - feature:/linux-64::__cuda==10.2=0 - feature:|@/linux-64::__cuda==10.2=0 Your installed CUDA driver is: 10.2 ```
2. Also there is an issue that you must pin `traits>=6` and `traitsui>=6` not just `pyface>=7` otherwise traits 5.2.0 gets installed, then when you actually try to use it there is an error. Removing the `traits` and `traitsui` pinning the env gets created, but then `python -c "import pyface"` you get:
Additional traceback ``` (bad) larsoner@bunk:~/python/mne-python$ python -c "from traitsui.api import View" Traceback (most recent call last): File "", line 1, in File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traitsui/api.py", line 36, in from .editors.api import ArrayEditor File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traitsui/editors/__init__.py", line 23, in from .api import ArrayEditor File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traitsui/editors/api.py", line 24, in from .code_editor import CodeEditor File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traitsui/editors/code_editor.py", line 37, in class ToolkitEditorFactory(EditorFactory): File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traitsui/editors/code_editor.py", line 49, in ToolkitEditorFactory mark_color = Color(0xECE9D8) File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traits/traits.py", line 655, in __call__ return self.maker_function(*args, **metadata) File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traits/traits.py", line 1414, in Color return ColorTrait(*args, **metadata) File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traitsui/toolkit_traits.py", line 8, in ColorTrait return toolkit().color_trait(*args, **traits) File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/traitsui/toolkit.py", line 109, in toolkit _toolkit = find_toolkit('traitsui.toolkits') File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pyface/base_toolkit.py", line 279, in find_toolkit toolkit = plugin.load() File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2460, in load self.require(*args, **kwargs) File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 2483, in require items = working_set.resolve(reqs, env, installer, extras=self.extras) File "/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages/pkg_resources/__init__.py", line 790, in resolve raise VersionConflict(dist, req).with_context(dependent_req) pkg_resources.ContextualVersionConflict: (traits 5.2.0 (/home/larsoner/anaconda3/envs/bad/lib/python3.8/site-packages), Requirement.parse('traits>=6'), {'pyface'}) ```
### Steps to Reproduce env_bad.yml ``` dependencies: - python>=3.7 - traits>=6 - pyface>=7 - traitsui>=6 ``` bash ``` $ conda env create -n bad -f env_bad.yml ``` ## Expected Behavior Create a usable env ## Environment Information
`conda info`

``` ```

`conda config --show-sources`

``` ```

`conda list --show-channel-urls`

``` ```

So it seems like the dependencies for traits/traitsui/pyface are messed up in some way.

items.title: Cannot create env in Conda 4.8.3

items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences
items.body:
## Current Behavior

Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences. This can be fixed by using raw strings or escaping the literals. pyupgrade also helps in automatic conversion : https://github.com/asottile/pyupgrade/

### Steps to Reproduce

```
find . -iname '*.py' | grep -Ev 'vendor|example|doc' | xargs -P4 -I{} python3.8 -Wall -m py_compile {}          
./conda/core/subdir_data.py:56: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \}
  REPODATA_HEADER_RE = b'"(_etag|_mod|_cache_control)":[ ]?"(.*?[^\\\\])"[,\}\s]'  # NOQA
./conda/common/path.py:306: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \/
  path_re = '(?<![:/^a-zA-Z])([a-zA-Z]:[\/\\\\]+(?:[^:*?"<>|]+[\/\\\\]+)*[^:*?"<>|;\/\\\\]+?(?![a-zA-Z]:))'  # noqa
./conda/gateways/disk/link.py:211: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \ 
  """
./conda/gateways/disk/link.py:250: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \*
  """
./conda/gateways/disk/create.py:85: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \.
  python_entry_point_template = dals("""
./test_data/env_metadata/__init__.py:4: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \(
  """
```

Elapsed: 00:00.209747
CF-RAY: 5b261614c86ee72c-EWR

An HTTP error occurred when trying to retrieve this URL.
HTTP errors are often intermittent, and a simple retry will get you on your way.`

This error occurs when trying to run either of the following commands (using the attached text files):

items.title: ***NEW*** Connection error ( HTTP 000 CONNECTION FAILED)
items.body:
## Current Behavior Every package I try to install results in a connection error (HTTP 000 CONNECTION FAILED). I had installed Conda a couple of months ago and everything was running great, and then after trying to install the variable inspector extension for Jupyter I noticed that Spyder wasn't launching (I used Jupyer notebooks until that point). I tried opening the Conda navigator and it didn't launch too. Eventually I uninstalled and reinstalled and that is when everything went bad and now I can't restore any Conda packages/environments, etc. It all turns up with this connection error. I've tried following the steps in [this](https://github.com/conda/conda/issues/9555) issue, including defining the PATH, copying the .dll files to the DLLs folder, clean reinstallation of both Anaconda 3 and Miniconda. Nothing, it gives the exact same error every time. I was able to install packages from the command window using pip (after I defined the PATH, of course), but that doesn't solve the problem since I can't use them (e.g. Jupyter). I am not sure this is a server issue because this works: ``` conda --version conda 4.8.3 ``` ### Steps to Reproduce Install the variable inspector extension as explained [here](https://jupyter-contrib-nbextensions.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install.html#install-the-python-package). After that, uninstall and reinstall Miniconda3 (or Anaconda3, I've also tried that). Then run any Conda command from the Conda prompt to get the connection error, e.g.: ``` conda install jupyter Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): failed CondaHTTPError: HTTP 000 CONNECTION FAILED for url Elapsed: - An HTTP error occurred when trying to retrieve this URL. HTTP errors are often intermittent, and a simple retry will get you on your way. 'http://localhost:3141/root/pypi/ simple/win-64' ``` ## Expected Behavior After typing Conda install _____ I expect to see the package installed and launchable. After typing anaconda-navigator I expect the navigator to launch. ## Environment Information

items.title: Important Feature Request: Add activate & deactivate commands to conda.cli.python_api
items.body:
<!--
Hi!  Read this; it's important.

This is an issue tracker for conda -- the package manager.  File feature requests
for conda here, as well as bug reports about something conda has messed up.

Anaconda Community Code of Conduct: https://www.anaconda.com/community-code-of-conduct/

If your issue is a feature request for:
  * a specific conda package from Anaconda ('defaults' channel):
      ==> file at https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues
  * a specific conda package from conda-forge:
      ==> file at the corresponding feedstock under https://github.com/conda-forge
  * repo.anaconda.com access and service:
      ==> file at https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues
  * anaconda.org access and service:
      ==> file at https://anaconda.org/contact/report
  * commands under 'conda build':
      ==> file at https://github.com/conda/conda-build
  * commands under 'conda env':
      ==> please file it here!
  * all other conda commands that start with 'conda':
      ==> please file it here!

-->
## Introduction
Hello, first of all I just wanna thank all developers of conda for making such awesome project. I was really frustrated when using tools such as venv, pipenv and et al. but conda is something else, it was easy to setup, and having many versions of python running on different environments was easy and straightforward.
I am currently making a project called [lazyconda](https://github.com/ahmedkhalf/lazyconda) which aims to make calling conda commands even simpler by utilizing an interactive TUI (terminal UI). This project has been inspired by other terminal UI's like lazygit and lazydocker. And has been fueled by my urge of eliminating the need of googling for a command every time I need to do something complex.

## Problem
Okay, now that you have enough background on why I'm making this issue it's time to tackle the problem I encountered when using conda.cli.python_api. When making my project, I wanted a simple way of activating/changing the current environment in the open shell using python. I tried many ways of doing so:

- Creating a shell using a subprocess with "conda activate"
- Changing os.environ

But this does not change the conda environment in my current shell because as far as I know changing environment variables has no effect on the parent shell but only on the children of the python script.

## Conclusion
Okay so now seeing that in conda you can call "conda activate" (which I believe is the children of the shell?? and cannot change it's environment variables of parent shell if so) is there a way of activating an environment from python? How does conda tackle this problem? And could you add support for activate Command in `conda.cli.python_api`?

Thank you for reading up to this point :). Here is an [image of lazyconda](https://imgur.com/axLTrSJ) at the moment if you are interested.

items.title: Release GIL
items.body:
I believe that there is a period during execution when Conda does not release the GIL.  

This doesn't affect the common case user and so isn't a priority, but I'm trying to solve multiple conda environments in parallel and would find this convenient.  As a workaround I'm happy to use processes, but if this is easy to do it might be worth doing as a matter of hygiene.  Feel free to close as low priority though if there is a lot more going on.

items.title: Seemingly incorrect dependency UnsatisfiableError
items.body:
## Steps to reproduce ``` conda create -n temp trtools python=3.8 ``` Output ``` Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done Solving environment: failed with repodata from current_repodata.json, will retry with next repodata source. Collecting package metadata (repodata.json): done Solving environment: - Found conflicts! Looking for incompatible packages. This can take several minutes. Press CTRL-C to abort. failed UnsatisfiableError: The following specifications were found to be incompatible with each other: Output in format: Requested package -> Available versions Package python conflicts for: trtools -> python[version='>=3.5'] python=3.8 trtools -> argparse -> python[version='2.6.*|3.6.*|3.5.*|3.4.*|2.7.*|>=3.8,<3.9.0a0|>=3.6,<3.7.0a0|>=3.7,<3.8.0a0|>=2.7,<2.8.0a0|>=3.5,<3.6.0a0|<3.0.0'] ``` It seems like python=3.8 should satisfy all three of those requirements, I don't understand why it doesn't. ## Environment Information

items.title: Creating environment from .yml doesn't run scripts
items.body:
## Current Behavior
After creating an environment which contains Jupyter Notebook, i export it to a .yml file using `conda env export > environment.yml`. Note that after installing Jupyter it creates shortcuts in the start menu, in the same folder as the conda prompt shortcuts.
I then try to create an environment from this file using `conda env create -f environment.yml`. Everything installs but there are no Jupyter shortcuts in the start menu. These shortcuts are created at the end of an install, by running a script created by Jupyter. This doesn't seem to happen when installing from an yml file.


### Steps to Reproduce
On the first computer:
```
conda create -n environment python=3.8
conda activate environment
conda install Jupyter
conda env export > environment.yml
```
On another computer:
```
conda env create -f environment.yml
```

## Expected Behavior
Shortcuts to launch a Jupyter notebook should exist on the second computer, in the start menu, under the Anaconda3 menu.

I may not be correct about why this issue is occuring, but the only variable is the mechanism of creating an environment from a yml file. One would expect that the yml file would be used as a list of packages that need to be installed that would then be passed to `conda install`, but that doesn't seem to be the case.

Thank you.

items.title: Installer hash doesn't match
items.body:
## Current Behavior Hash of `Miniconda3-latest-MacOSX-x86_64.sh` doesn't match the one on the website. The hash is still the one for `v4.8.2` as seen on the [miniconda hash information](https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/miniconda_hashes.html) page, while the installer is for `v4.8.3`. ### Steps to Reproduce ```bash cd /tmp curl -O https://repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/Miniconda3-latest-MacOSX-x86_64.sh shasum -a 256 Miniconda3-latest-MacOSX-x86_64.sh # ccc1bded923a790cd61cd17c83c3dcc374dc0415cfa7fb1f71e6a2438236543d Miniconda3-latest-MacOSX-x86_64.sh openssl dgst -sha256 Miniconda3-latest-MacOSX-x86_64.sh # SHA256(Miniconda3-latest-MacOSX-x86_64.sh)= ccc1bded923a790cd61cd17c83c3dcc374dc0415cfa7fb1f71e6a2438236543d ``` ## Expected Behavior website should be updated with the correct hash. [Instructions on verifying hashes](https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda/en/latest/user-guide/install/download.html#hash-verification) should be updated to: - actually tell a user to compare the hashes - give instructions on what to do when the hashes don't match ## Environment Information
`conda info`

``` #!/bin/sh # # NAME: Miniconda3 # VER: py37_4.8.3 # PLAT: osx-64 # LINES: 569 # MD5: 7e4514208db7df698acbc4defb149699 ```

System details

- MacOS High Sierra v10.13.1

items.title: 'conda create --dry-run --yes' deletes existing environment.
items.body:
## Current Behavior If `--dry-run` and `--yes` are _both_ passed to `conda create`, and the named environment already exists, the named environment is deleted. ### Steps to Reproduce ``` # create the env conda create -n tmp -y conda env list | grep tmp # --dry-run without --yes leaves env in place conda create -n tmp --dry-run conda env list | grep tmp # --dry-run with --yes deletes the env conda create -n tmp --dry-run --yes conda env list | grep tmp ``` ## Expected Behavior 'conda create --dry-run' should not delete an existing environment. ## Environment Information

items.title: Windows vs Linux envs python3 vs python
items.body:
## Current Behavior When creating a conda environment under Linux python3 is sym linked to python, under Windows there is only a single executable - python.exe. This inconsistency is posing an issue with some tools moving forward - specifically Emacs flycheck which is configured to use python3 as an executable when running flake8 and other linters. Rather than a bug this is more of a question, what is the intended direction for these changes to make them consistent? If the symlink on Linux is removed Flycheck will fail to work on those platforms as well so ultimately I need to coordinate with the flycheck authors to make them aware that this is currently failing in conda environments. Of course the simple work around for Windows is to simply make a copy of python.exe to python3.exe but it's a pain to remember when creating new environments I'd rather flycheck be able to cope with this in future. ## Environment Information
`conda info`

``` active environment : base active env location : f:\util\Miniconda3 shell level : 1 user config file : C:\Users\\.condarc populated config files : conda version : 4.8.3 conda-build version : not installed python version : 3.7.6.final.0 virtual packages : base environment : f:\util\Miniconda3 (writable) channel URLs : https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/msys2/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/msys2/noarch package cache : f:\util\Miniconda3\pkgs C:\Users\\.conda\pkgs C:\Users\\AppData\Local\conda\conda\pkgs envs directories : f:\util\Miniconda3\envs C:\Users\\.conda\envs C:\Users\\AppData\Local\conda\conda\envs platform : win-64 user-agent : conda/4.8.3 requests/2.23.0 CPython/3.7.6 Windows/10 Windows/10.0.18362 administrator : False netrc file : None offline mode : False ```

items.title: Conda environment is activated, however the python console says the environment is not activated
items.body:
## Current Behavior I am following the conda documentation as well as the troubleshooting guide in order to create a new environment on a Windows machine, activate it, and then enter into the python console. I can see that the environment is active, however, python console gives me the warning that the environment is not active. Furthermore, trying to import a module (numpy) that I installed in the current conda environment fails as it instead tries to load it from the base conda environment (this is a whole different headache). ### Steps to Reproduce The following are the exact steps that I have used: 1. Install Anaconda on a Windows machine (version details in section Environment Information below) 2. Download numpy tar file from conda-forge 3. Create a project folder 4. Open Anaconda Prompt (Powershell) as an Admin and cd to project folder 5. Run the conda commands listed below ``` conda create --prefix ./envs --offline conda activate /path/to/envs conda install /path/to/numpy/tar/from/conda-forge python ``` ## Expected Behavior 1. The Powershell should reflect that the active conda environment is envs. This behaviour is observed: 2. On running `python`, the python console should start without the "environment not activated" warning. This is **not the case**: Plaintext of warning message: > This Python interpreter is in a conda environment, but the environment has not been activated. Libraries may fail to load. To activate this environment please see https://conda.io/activation 3. Trying to load numpy fails as it tries to load from `C:\ProgramData\Anaconda` and not from the conda environment I created. ## Environment Information 1. OS: Windows Server 2016 (v10.0.14393) 2. Anaconda: V2020.02 py37_0 3. Conda: V4.8.2 I have admin access to the Windows machine. The windows machine does not have internet access (corporate environment).
`conda info`

``` active environment : D:\conda_project\envs active env location : D:\conda_project\envs shell level : 2 user config file : C:\Users\daspana\.condarc populated config files : conda version : 4.8.2 conda-build version : 3.18.11 python version : 3.7.6.final.0 virtual packages : base environment : C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3 (writable) channel URLs : https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/msys2/win-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/msys2/noarch package cache : C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\pkgs C:\Users\daspana\.conda\pkgs C:\Users\daspana\AppData\Local\conda\conda\pkgs envs directories : C:\ProgramData\Anaconda3\envs C:\Users\daspana\.conda\envs C:\Users\daspana\AppData\Local\conda\conda\envs platform : win-64 user-agent : conda/4.8.2 requests/2.22.0 CPython/3.7.6 Windows/10 Windows/10.0.14393 administrator : True netrc file : None offline mode : False ``` This is what the system PATH looks like:

`conda config --show-sources`

Running conda config --show-sources returns nothing

`conda list --show-channel-urls`

``` # packages in environment at D:\conda_project\envs: # # Name Version Build Channel numpy 1.18.4 py37hae9e721_0 ```

items.title: Miniconda doesn't install NumPy with MKL
items.body:
## Current Behavior I found out that my installation of Miniconda used OpenBLAS instead of MKL. I removed it with `rm -rf ~/anaconda3`, and do a fresh install. However, when I installed Miniconda, it already came with OpenBLAS NumPy, as seen in `np.show_config()`: ``` blas_mkl_info: NOT AVAILABLE blis_info: NOT AVAILABLE openblas_info: libraries = ['openblas', 'openblas'] library_dirs = ['/usr/local/lib'] language = c define_macros = [('HAVE_CBLAS', None)] blas_opt_info: libraries = ['openblas', 'openblas'] library_dirs = ['/usr/local/lib'] language = c define_macros = [('HAVE_CBLAS', None)] lapack_mkl_info: NOT AVAILABLE openblas_lapack_info: libraries = ['openblas', 'openblas'] library_dirs = ['/usr/local/lib'] language = c define_macros = [('HAVE_CBLAS', None)] lapack_opt_info: libraries = ['openblas', 'openblas'] library_dirs = ['/usr/local/lib'] language = c define_macros = [('HAVE_CBLAS', None)] ``` ### Steps to Reproduce ```bash % Download https://repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/Miniconda3-latest-Linux-x86_64.sh bash Miniconda3-latest-Linux-x86_64.sh % conda init cd ~/miniconda3/bin ./conda init zsh ``` ## Expected Behavior Miniconda & Anaconda should come with MKL. ## Environment Information

items.title: Development environment packages
items.body:
Hi. 

I noticed that there is no way to install packages for development environment. It is very unconfortable to remove manually `dev_dependencies` from `environment.yml` file. Cool option to solve this problem is to add dev section to environment file and `--dev` flag to command `conda install`. Good example is `pipenv` package.

items.title: UnavailableInvalidChannel: The channel is not accessible or is invalid.
items.body:
## Current Behavior Conda fails to install a package that is available from the available channels ### Steps to Reproduce ``` conda install -c bioconda -y recognizer Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): failed UnavailableInvalidChannel: The channel is not accessible or is invalid. channel name: bioconda channel url: https://conda.anaconda.org/bioconda error code: 403 You will need to adjust your conda configuration to proceed. items.title: Failed to import installed packages (ModuleNotFoundError) in Computing Cluster
items.body:
## Background I'm using conda to create an environment for running my codes in a computing cluster where I don't have sudo access. Every time I log in, I need to load some python module to use conda. I use a .yml file to create the environment, which is provided by my collaborator exporting his environment on another cluster. I used this to create an environment on another computer and it worked. But now I'm using a cluster that is new to me, and I can't get the codes running. ## Current Behavior After creating the environment using the .yml file, I used ``` conda list ``` to check the installed packages and no package is missing. However, when I'm running my codes with ``` python myscript.py --arguments ``` I got ModuleNotFoundError for several of my packages. Namely, they are TensorFlow-related packages, qutip, nevergrad and quspin. All other packages worked well. I tried to use ``` conda install ``` as well as ``` conda remove ``` several times but they just don't work. Then I used pip to install them and it worked. Those installed by pip can be imported. However, I noticed that the versions of the packages installed by pip don't match those I found in conda list. For Tensorflow itself, I didn't use pip but chose a module with built-in TensorFlow version 2.1.0 instead, which don't match the version shown by 'conda list'(1.14.0, same as that in the .yml file). I tested the actual behavior, it behaves as version 2.1.0 instead of 1.14.0 But the package quspin can't be installed by pip. They only support conda install. So I'm stuck here. I also tried ``` python setup.py install ``` after download but it didn't work either. ### Steps to Reproduce I don't know how to reproduce this in another device as this only occurred in a computing cluster, which is something I'm not familiar with. ## Expected Behavior These packages can be imported. ## Environment Information
`conda info`

``` active environment : base active env location : /global/software/sl-7.x86_64/modules/langs/python/3.6 shell level : 1 user config file : /global/home/users/zhibo_w_yang/.condarc populated config files : /global/home/users/zhibo_w_yang/.condarc conda version : 4.8.2 conda-build version : not installed python version : 3.6.8.final.0 virtual packages : __glibc=2.17 base environment : /global/software/sl-7.x86_64/modules/langs/python/3.6 (read only) channel URLs : https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/linux-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/linux-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/noarch https://conda.anaconda.org/conda-forge/linux-64 https://conda.anaconda.org/conda-forge/noarch package cache : /global/software/sl-7.x86_64/modules/langs/python/3.6/pkgs /global/home/users/zhibo_w_yang/.conda/pkgs envs directories : /global/home/users/zhibo_w_yang/.conda/envs /global/software/sl-7.x86_64/modules/langs/python/3.6/envs platform : linux-64 user-agent : conda/4.8.2 requests/2.22.0 CPython/3.6.8 Linux/3.10.0-693.11.6.el7.x86_64 scientific/7.4 glibc/2.17 UID:GID : 44567:501 netrc file : None offline mode : False ```

items.title: Python 3.8 and incompatible CUDA drivers
items.body:
## Current Behavior
<!-- What actually happens?
     If you want to include console output, please use "Steps to Reproduce" below. -->
In a python 3.8 environment, the following type of error occurs when installing two entirely separate packages:
```
The following specifications were found to be incompatible with your CUDA driver:

  - feature:/linux-64::__cuda==10.2=0

Your installed CUDA driver is: 10.2
```
You can see specifically what I mean in [this spyder-feedstock issue](https://github.com/conda-forge/spyder-feedstock/issues/72#issuecomment-581081100), and [this pytorch-metric-learning issue](https://github.com/KevinMusgrave/pytorch-metric-learning/issues/55#issue-600601602). In both cases, users find that switching to python 3.7 fixes the problem. Also, here's a [stackoverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61072464/anaconda-integration-with-cuda-9-0-shows-incompatible-package-error) in which the user has the same incompatible CUDA error when installing PyTorch.

This problem is difficult to debug because the error message says the CUDA driver is incompatible, even though the driver numbers match.


### Steps to Reproduce
<!-- If the current behavior is a bug, please provide specific, minimal steps to independently reproduce.
     Include the exact conda commands that reproduce the issue and their output between the ticks below. -->
In a python 3.8 environment:
```
conda install spyder
```
or
```
conda install pytorch-metric-learning
```

## Expected Behavior
<!-- What do you think should happen? -->
The CUDA driver should be compatible, or the provided error message should be more informative.

## Environment Information
Here is an environment one user posted in the pytorch-metric-learning repo:
```
channels:
  - anaconda
  - conda-forge
  # - nodefaults
dependencies:
  - anaconda::flake8
  - anaconda::nb_conda
  - anaconda::notebook
  - anaconda::pandas
  - anaconda::pip
  - anaconda::pylint
  - anaconda::pytest
  - anaconda::python=3.8
  - conda-forge::black
  - conda-forge::jupyter_contrib_nbextensions
  - conda-forge::nb_black
  - nodejs
  - pip
```

items.title: AppVeyor Suitability
items.body:
The Windows test suite often exceeds AppVeyor's 60 minute build limit.  When the time limit expires, the test runner is killed and the run is failed. These false-negatives add friction to the development process and diminish utility of the testing code.

Hoping to start a discussion on this topic, here are a few paths forward (may very well be others that I don't have visibility into):

1. Ask AppVeyor to relax the build limit for conda.  Even if they would relax the limit for the main conda project, community members will be unable to reliably run the test suite.
2. Make the unit and integration tests faster.  This would be great, but is no small undertaking. AppVeyor's 60 minute build limit is quite restrictive and out of line with other platforms. Why commit to a permanent, on-going battle against exogenous test failures?
3. Transition the Windows tests to a different CI platform. This seems to be the most viable path.

I'm willing to contribute to the effort, but would like some guidance from maintainers before investing too much time.

To move the conversation forward with respect to option 3 above, a few candidate CI platforms immediately come to mind:

- Circle CI: The Linux tests are currently hosted on Circle CI, so that would be a natural choice for the Windows tests too. Unfortunately, the free tier would limit community users to only one or two runs of the full Windows test suite per week; i.e. Circle CI free tier currently offers 2,500 credits per week. Windows builds consume 40 credits/minute x ~40 minutes/run. It is possible there are more cost effective ways to run the Windows test suite on the Circle CI platform, so don't take that as a final answer.
- Azure Pipelines: Offers solid support for Windows platforms. Other major python projects (such as pandas) utilize Azure Pipelines, so it is reasonable to expect it would serve conda too.
- GitHub CI: I have no experience with this offering, but it deserves a look.

items.title: get_python_version_for_prefix in prefix_data.py doesn't handle two digit minor version
items.body:
The function `get_python_version_for_prefix` silently truncates two digit minor version numbers. For example, if the Python version number is 3.10, it will return "3.1", which can cause some packages to be installed in the incorrect location.

Of course, there isn't a Python 3.10 yet -- I ran into this while experimenting. FWIW, the accepted [PEP 602](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0602/) suggests that 3.10 will be the version after 3.9 (as opposed to 4.0). 

https://github.com/conda/conda/blob/2cdd7ab052c2b96c088137f52dc40c613e99ce33/conda/core/prefix_data.py#L370-L380

items.title: Specify yml file AND dont install default packages. --no-default-packages doesnt work with -f environment.yml
items.body:
- I want to describe my dependencies in a yaml file 
- I dont want to install any default packages

Pretty straight forward use case but this seems to be impossible?

- I cant use `--no-default-packages` with `conda env create -f environment.yml` 
- I cant use `--f environment.yml` with `conda create --name myenv python`
- If I run `conda create --name myenv python` first and then run `conda env update --name myenv --file environment.yml` it installs all those default packages!!!

Am I crazy? there must be a way to do this. If I have to write my own script that parses environment.yml and runs a command to install each dep individually that would be super shitty

items.title: cudatoolkit run constrain on __cuda not used for solve
items.body:
## Current Behavior Recently we added a repodata patch to `cudatoolkit` to constrain its version based on the `__cuda` virtual package's version ( https://github.com/AnacondaRecipes/repodata-hotfixes/pull/81 ) (IOW the max version of CUDA the GPU driver will support). However it seems this isn't respected when installing `cudatoolkit`. Instead one needs to prod `conda` a bit to get it to consider `__cuda`. ### Steps to Reproduce Running the following does not take into account the `__cuda` version supported.
``` conda create -d -n test_cuda cudatoolkit ``` ``` Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done Solving environment: done ## Package Plan ## environment location: /home/ubuntu/miniforge/envs/test_cuda added / updated specs: - cudatoolkit The following packages will be downloaded: package | build ---------------------------|----------------- _libgcc_mutex-0.1 | main 3 KB cudatoolkit-10.2.89 | hfd86e86_0 539.3 MB libgcc-ng-9.1.0 | hdf63c60_0 8.1 MB libstdcxx-ng-9.1.0 | hdf63c60_0 4.0 MB ------------------------------------------------------------ Total: 551.5 MB The following NEW packages will be INSTALLED: _libgcc_mutex pkgs/main/linux-64::_libgcc_mutex-0.1-main cudatoolkit pkgs/main/linux-64::cudatoolkit-10.2.89-hfd86e86_0 libgcc-ng pkgs/main/linux-64::libgcc-ng-9.1.0-hdf63c60_0 libstdcxx-ng pkgs/main/linux-64::libstdcxx-ng-9.1.0-hdf63c60_0 DryRunExit: Dry run. Exiting. ```
However adding `__cuda` to the install spec does work.
``` conda create -d -n test_cuda __cuda cudatoolkit ``` ``` Collecting package metadata (current_repodata.json): done Solving environment: done ## Package Plan ## environment location: /home/ubuntu/miniforge/envs/test_cuda added / updated specs: - __cuda - cudatoolkit The following packages will be downloaded: package | build ---------------------------|----------------- cudatoolkit-10.1.243 | h6bb024c_0 513.2 MB ------------------------------------------------------------ Total: 513.2 MB The following NEW packages will be INSTALLED: cudatoolkit pkgs/main/linux-64::cudatoolkit-10.1.243-h6bb024c_0 DryRunExit: Dry run. Exiting. ```
Interestingly we also observe compiler runtime packages installed in the first case, but not in the second. Unclear on why that happens, but may also be related to the same issue. ## Expected Behavior When installing `cudatoolkit` or really anything that depends on `cudatoolkit`, `__cuda` should be factored into the solve. ## Environment Information
`conda info`

items.title: `conda env export -f base.yaml` sometimes produces an empty output file
items.body:
## Current Behavior After installing conda 4.6, `conda env export -f base.yaml` produces an empty output file. ### Steps to Reproduce This is not reproducible, it happens sometimes and disappears as suddenly as it happened. Checking the conda 4.6.1 source code at https://github.com/conda/conda/blob/6461a1abe4c255424104913ab6d089c9453cba4e/conda_env/cli/main_export.py#L105 it looks like the output file is not being closed: ```python if args.file is None: print(env.to_yaml()) else: fp = open(args.file, 'wb') env.to_yaml(stream=fp) ``` To confirm, I tried this when I hit the issue again: ```sh source activate base conda env export > base.yml ls -l conda env export -f base.yml ls -l sed -Ei -e 's/(env.to_yaml\(stream=fp\))/\1; fp.close()/' ${CONDA_HOME}/lib/python3.7/site-packages/conda_env/cli/main_export.py conda env export -f base.yml ls -l ``` which yields ``` total 8 -rw-rw-r-- 1 wsbuild wsbuild 1046 Apr 26 20:05 base.yml total 4 -rw-rw-r-- 1 wsbuild wsbuild 0 Apr 26 20:05 base.yml total 8 -rw-rw-r-- 1 wsbuild wsbuild 1045 Apr 26 20:05 base.yml ``` So: - redirecting the output of `conda env export` works - writing to a file with `conda env export -f` creates an empty file - after patching `fp.close()` in **main_export.py**, `conda env export -f` also works. While I am experiencing this issue in conda 4.6, it seems the latest version still does not close the file: https://github.com/conda/conda/blob/13dac97e3ff2f11339b3185321f42aca0da1c6f0/conda_env/cli/main_export.py#L117. ## Expected Behavior The exported **base.yaml** file should not be empty. ## Environment Information
`conda info`

``` active environment : base active env location : /opt/conda shell level : 1 user config file : /home/wsbuild/.condarc populated config files : /opt/conda/.condarc conda version : 4.6.14 conda-build version : not installed python version : 3.7.3.final.0 base environment : /opt/conda (writable) channel URLs : https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/linux-64 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch package cache : /opt/conda/pkgs /home/wsbuild/.conda/pkgs envs directories : /opt/conda/envs /home/wsbuild/.conda/envs platform : linux-64 user-agent : conda/4.6.14 requests/2.21.0 CPython/3.7.3 Linux/5.3.0-46-generic rhel/7.8 glibc/2.17 UID:GID : 3000:3000 netrc file : None offline mode : False ```

`conda config --show-sources`

``` ==> /opt/conda/.condarc <== auto_update_conda: False notify_outdated_conda: False default_channels: - https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main always_yes: True ```

`conda list --show-channel-urls`

``` # packages in environment at /opt/conda: # # Name Version Build Channel _libgcc_mutex 0.1 main defaults asn1crypto 0.24.0 py37_0 defaults ca-certificates 2020.1.1 0 defaults certifi 2020.4.5.1 py37_0 defaults cffi 1.12.2 py37h2e261b9_1 defaults chardet 3.0.4 py37_1 defaults conda 4.6.14 py37_0 defaults cryptography 2.5 py37h1ba5d50_0 defaults idna 2.8 py37_0 defaults libedit 3.1.20181209 hc058e9b_0 defaults libffi 3.2.1 hd88cf55_4 defaults libgcc-ng 8.2.0 hdf63c60_1 defaults libstdcxx-ng 8.2.0 hdf63c60_1 defaults ncurses 6.1 he6710b0_1 defaults openssl 1.1.1g h7b6447c_0 defaults pcre 8.43 he6710b0_0 defaults pip 19.2.3 py37_0 defaults pycosat 0.6.3 py37h14c3975_0 defaults pycparser 2.19 py37_0 defaults pyopenssl 19.0.0 py37_0 defaults pysocks 1.6.8 py37_0 defaults python 3.7.3 h0371630_0 defaults readline 7.0 h7b6447c_5 defaults requests 2.21.0 py37_0 defaults ruamel_yaml 0.15.46 py37h14c3975_0 defaults setuptools 41.0.0 py37_0 defaults six 1.12.0 py37_0 defaults sqlite 3.28.0 h7b6447c_0 defaults swig 3.0.12 h38cdd7d_3 defaults tk 8.6.8 hbc83047_0 defaults urllib3 1.24.1 py37_0 defaults wheel 0.33.1 py37_0 defaults xz 5.2.4 h14c3975_4 defaults yaml 0.1.7 had09818_2 defaults zlib 1.2.11 h7b6447c_3 defaults ```

items.title: "which conda"  command is not working
items.body:
I just recently installed conda and saw changes on my zshell command-line interface. A bug I observed is below, the command which conda does not provide a correct description of the conda package.

(base)MacBook-Pro-2017-i7 ~ % **which conda**
conda () {
	if [ "$#" -lt 1 ]
	then
		"$CONDA_EXE" $_CE_M $_CE_CONDA
	else
		\local cmd="$1"
		shift
		case "$cmd" in
			(activate | deactivate) __conda_activate "$cmd" "$@" ;;
			(install | update | upgrade | remove | uninstall) CONDA_INTERNAL_OLDPATH="${PATH}" 
				__add_sys_prefix_to_path
				"$CONDA_EXE" $_CE_M $_CE_CONDA "$cmd" "$@"
				\local t1=$?
				PATH="${CONDA_INTERNAL_OLDPATH}" 
				if [ $t1 = 0 ]
				then
					__conda_reactivate
				else
					return $t1
				fi ;;
			(*) CONDA_INTERNAL_OLDPATH="${PATH}" 
				__add_sys_prefix_to_path
				"$CONDA_EXE" $_CE_M $_CE_CONDA "$cmd" "$@"
				\local t1=$?
				PATH="${CONDA_INTERNAL_OLDPATH}" 
				return $t1 ;;
		esac
	fi
}

items.title: Request: don't issue clobber warnings / errors for identical files
items.body:
I've recently run into an issue where an identical file is packaged into separate packages. (conda-forge/jaraco.collections-feedstock#4 and jaraco/jaraco.collections#6). This is of course not a very big problem, but ideally I would like conda to not raise a clobber warning / error in these cases.

Would it be feasible to compare file hashes before doing the clobber check, and suppress the clobber warning if the files are identical?

items.title: url as channel name breaks splitting channel_subdir_str by slash
items.body:
https://github.com/conda/conda/blob/125413caa9384ae5e9e3e2dfcb4616ec33b7aadb/conda/models/match_spec.py#L186

I have a weird issue where `channel_subdir_str` is an url instead of a simple channel name (https://repo.continuum.io/pkgs/main/osx-64). The split then fails with

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/Users/christian/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda/exceptions.py", line 1079, in __call__
        return func(*args, **kwargs)
      File "/Users/christian/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda/cli/main.py", line 84, in _main
        exit_code = do_call(args, p)
      File "/Users/christian/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda/cli/conda_argparse.py", line 82, in do_call
        return getattr(module, func_name)(args, parser)
      File "/Users/christian/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda/cli/main_install.py", line 20, in execute
        install(args, parser, 'install')
      File "/Users/christian/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda/cli/install.py", line 250, in install
        index)
      File "/Users/christian/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda/plan.py", line 289, in revert_actions
        target_state = {MatchSpec.from_dist_str(dist_str) for dist_str in h.get_state(revision)}
      File "/Users/christian/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda/plan.py", line 289, in <setcomp>
        target_state = {MatchSpec.from_dist_str(dist_str) for dist_str in h.get_state(revision)}
      File "/Users/christian/miniconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda/models/match_spec.py", line 186, in from_dist_str
        channel_str, subdir = channel_subdir_str.split('/', 2)
    ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 2)
```

items.title: How to use old conda environment from another disk
items.body:
hi everyone, I met a problem that I can\`t use my conda environment.
For some reason, I changed my computer\`s disk and I create many conda environment on that disk. I forgot to export the conda env before I change it. New I can find those env folders. I want to use the old conda environment on that disk(or just export it to a .yml or requirements.txt file). I tried to install a new conda on the new disk to export the env on the old disk, but it can\`t find the environment and didn\`t work. 
How can I do that? It\`s very important to me. Thanks a lot!!!
os: win10

items.title: Issues facing installing NLTK Package
items.body:
Facing the below issue, please suggest:

>conda search nltk_data
Fetching package metadata ....
WARNING: The remote server could not find the noarch directory for the
requested channel with url: https://anaconda.****:**/gtgold

It is possible you have given conda an invalid channel. Please double-check
your conda configuration using `conda config --show`.

If the requested url is in fact a valid conda channel, please request that the
channel administrator create `noarch/repodata.json` and associated
`noarch/repodata.json.bz2` files, even if `noarch/repodata.json` is empty.
$ mkdir noarch
$ echo '{}' > noarch/repodata.json
$ bzip2 -k noarch/repodata.json

items.title: Can't export all jupyter lab extensions via conda export
items.body:
I tried to use `conda env export > xxx.yml ` to export a venv contains three jupyter lab extension:
```bash
(geo-spatial) C:\Users\pengz>jupyter labextension list
JupyterLab v1.2.6
Known labextensions:
   app dir: C:\Conda\envs\geo-spatial\share\jupyter\lab
        @jupyter-widgets/jupyterlab-manager v1.1.0 enabled  ok
        @jupyterlab/toc v2.0.0 enabled  ok
        jupyter-matplotlib v0.7.2 enabled  ok

```

but after I tried to create new venv from yaml file, only got `jupyter-matplotlib`:

```
(test) C:\Users\pengz>jupyter labextension list
JupyterLab v1.2.6
Known labextensions:
   app dir: C:\Conda\envs\test\share\jupyter\lab
        jupyter-matplotlib v0.7.2 enabled  ok

Build recommended, please run `jupyter lab build`:
    jupyter-matplotlib needs to be included in build
```

items.title: Conda graphical installation package not installing
items.body: It appears to somewhat install the conda package, although not completely, as it prompts that conda is already installed. The conda graphical installation package reaches the last step(Summary) in the installation and it crashes.

items.title: anaconda3 on raspberry Pi 4 (4Gb ram) - 'conda list' not working
items.body:
## Current Behavior
Hi, I recently got a raspberry Pi 4, with 4 Gb of memory.
I installed an anaconda distribution on it.
After creating a 'base' conda environment, I activate it and try to list all libraries installed, but conda list does not seem to work.
The error message mentions that Python 3.5 is required, and apparently only Python 3.4 is avbailable for Raspberry Pi 4, but does that mean I can't use conda at all ? Shall I expect the anaconda installation to be corrupt ? Shouln't conda have detected that it cannot be installed on a system with python 3.4 only ?

items.title: dyld: Library not loaded: @rpath/libssl.1.0.0.dylib

## Current Behavior Hello, I am trying to install lftp through conda on MacOS Catalina. I used the following command: conda install lftp When I call the program lftp. I get the following error: dyld: Library not loaded: @rpath/libssl.1.0.0.dylib Referenced from: /Users/user_name/miniconda3/bin/lftp Reason: image not found Abort trap: 6 ### Steps to Reproduce I uninstalled lftp, updated conda, and re-install lftp. items.title: Typo on Conda performance docs site?
items.body:
Hi I just tried to follow the instructions to set the channel_priority to strict, [here](https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda/en/latest/user-guide/concepts/conda-performance.html)

```
conda config -set channel_priority strict
``` 
as suggested, does not work. 
```
$ conda config -set channel_priority strict
usage: conda [-h] [-V] command ...
conda: error: unrecognized arguments: -set channel_priority strict
```

```
conda config --set channel_priority strict
```
does work.

items.title: --singularity-args arguments not being added to singularity call by snakemake
items.body:
Closed, as it's the wrong git repo to bring this up. Possible duplicate:
https://github.com/snakemake/snakemake/issues/193
https://github.com/snakemake/snakemake/issues/179

When running snakemake with use-singularity, adding a bind argument to the singularity-call using --singularity args, it does not affect the final singularity call. Snakemake call:

`snakemake --use-singularity --singularity-args '--bind /home/myhome' --cores 2 --snakefile ../src/Snakefile --configfile config.json`

Resulting singularity call (reported by snakemake after failing pipeline):

```

RuleException:
CalledProcessError in line 332 of /home/myhome/myproject/pipelines/smproject/src/Snakefile:
Command ' singularity exec --home /home/myhome/myproject/pipelines/smproject/config  --bind /home/myhome/anaconda3/envs/singularity/lib/python3.7/site-packages:/mnt/snakemake /home/myhome/myproject/pipelines/smproject/config/.snakemake/singularity/bc12f9f5dd66bf5a09489dfa07c45231.simg bash -c 'set -euo pipefail;  Rscript --vanilla /home/myhome/myproject/pipelines/smproject/config/.snakemake/scripts/tmpbg3dmmt3.checkParameterValidity.R'' returned non-zero exit status 1.
  File "/home/myhome/myproject/pipelines/smproject/src/Snakefile", line 332, in __rule_checkParameterValidity
  File "/home/myhome/anaconda3/envs/singularity/lib/python3.7/concurrent/futures/thread.py", line 57, in run
Shutting down, this might take some time.
Exiting because a job execution failed. Look above for error message
```

checkParameterValidity fails because it can't find a file, which should exist. The reason it cannot find it, is that the --bind parameter for singularity did not get passed on to singularity by snakemake. I'm digging through the snakemake source code in the hope I can find the reason for this issue. Any help is greatly appreciated.


I am using snakemake and singularity from within a conda environment.
```
(singularity) ➜  config git:(master) ✗ conda --version
conda 4.8.2
(singularity) ➜  config git:(master) ✗ singularity --version
singularity version d5eaf8a+dirty
(singularity) ➜  config git:(master) ✗ snakemake --version
5.11.1
(singularity) ➜  config git:(master) ✗
```

items.title: ERROR conda.core.link:_execute(507)
items.body:
## Current Behavior

Error when creating identical conda environment using `conda create --name <name> --file <specs>.txt`

Error Snippet
```
Preparing transaction: done
Verifying transaction: done
Executing transaction: failed
ERROR conda.core.link:_execute(507): An error occurred while installing package 'defaults::dask-core-1.2.2-py_0'.
FileNotFoundError(2, "No such file or directory: '/home/ubuntu/anaconda3/envs/my_env/bin/python2.7'")
Attempting to roll back.
```

Commenting out this line from my spec will make it work. And a conda environment successfully created. And without `dask-core-1.2.2` of course.
```
#https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/dask-core-1.2.2-py_0.tar.bz2
```

I then source activate the new environment and `conda install --yes dask-core==1.2.2` to see if this works, and yes it does.

I then used `conda list --explicit` to generate the specs from this environment because I wanted to check if i have installed the same version of `dask-core` that was mentioned in my original spec file. And the result is that they are the same. 
```
# this one is from my new spec file
 https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/dask-core-1.2.2-py_0.tar.bz2

# this is the one I commented out from my original spec file
#https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/dask-core-1.2.2-py_0.tar.bz2
```

Run `conda create --name myenv --file myspec`, and you will see
```
Preparing transaction: done
Verifying transaction: done
Executing transaction: failed
ERROR conda.core.link:_execute(507): An error occurred while installing package 'defaults::dask-core-1.2.2-py_0'.
FileNotFoundError(2, "No such file or directory: '/home/ubuntu/anaconda3/envs/my_env/bin/python2.7'")
Attempting to roll back.
```
Comment out below lines from `myspec` (comment out multiple of them because any of them will trigger the error)
```
https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/dask-core-1.2.2-py_0.tar.bz2
https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/defusedxml-0.6.0-py_0.tar.bz2
https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/jmespath-0.9.4-py_0.tar.bz2
```
Run `conda create --name myenv_again --file myspec`, and you will have the environment created. `source activate myenv_again` and run below commands to install those that can't be installed from `myspec`
```
conda install --yes dask-core==1.2.2
conda install --yes defusedxml==0.6.0
conda install --yes jmespath==0.9.4
```
generate another spec file from `myenv_again` conda environment with 
```
conda list --explicit > myspec_again
```
you should be able to find those lines which have been commented out from `myspec` appear in `myspec_again`.
```
https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/dask-core-1.2.2-py_0.tar.bz2
https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/defusedxml-0.6.0-py_0.tar.bz2
https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch/jmespath-0.9.4-py_0.tar.bz2
```

## Expected Behavior
`conda create --name myenv --file myspec` should create the conda environment without any issue.
